titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Walter Crane Collection
titlestmt.author: by Sandra Markham and Francesca Tancini

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday March 21, 2019 at 03:00

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired by gift and purchase, 1956-2016. For more information, see the finding aid.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: I. Correspondence, 1876-1915. II. Artwork and Writings, 1878-1909.

bioghist.head: Walter Crane (1845-1915)
bioghist.p: Walter Crane (1845-1915), English author and illustrator best known for his work in children's literature. Among the most important illustrators of the nineteenth century, Crane was also a painter, essayist, and decorative artist who created designs for wallpapers, tiles, printed textiles, posters, stained glass, embroideries, and pottery. His formal education consisted of an apprenticeship served with the wood engraver and illustrator W. J. Linton from 1858 to 1862; later he was a founder of The Art-Workers' Guild (1884) and a founder and first president of The Arts and Crafts Exhibition Society (1888).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Walter Crane Collection. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Prior to 2016, the manuscripts and artwork related to Walter Crane were kept together as one collection and primarily filed under the call number MS Vault Crane. When the material was processed in 2016 it was decided to extract and reassemble the Catharine T. Patterson Collection of Walter Crane (under call number GEN MSS 1386), and to describe the remaining Crane material—items purchased by the library or received as gifts from other donors—separately as the Walter Crane Collection (under GEN MSS 1418).

This finding aid was produced from a previously existing card set in the Manuscripts Catalog and the library's accession files; and all pertinent bibliographical information has been retained. The information drawn from those sources was greatly enhanced through the efforts of the Crane scholar Francesca Tancini, an A. Bartlett Giamatti Fellow at Beinecke Library in 2015, who examined all the Walter Crane material in the library's collection and cataloged the original (non-print) items. Many of her descriptions and narratives form the basis of this finding aid, and the library is enormously grateful for her careful work.
Former call numbers: MS Vault Crane, MS Vault Shelves Crane, Uncat MS Vault File

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains original sketches, drawings, autograph manuscripts, and autograph letters, signed, by the English illustrator Walter Crane. Prominent are the original drawings for two of Crane's illustrated books, Queen Summer, or The Tourney of the Lily and the Rose (London: Cassell & Co., 1891) and A Floral Fantasy in an Old English Garden (New York and London: Harper and Bros., 1899). Correspondents include Kineton Parkes and Frederic Shields. Also present is a ceramic tile bearing an image by Crane, and his watercolor landscape titled "Swedish Twilight."

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Walter Crane Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

did.unittitle: Folk and Fairy Tales , by Constance Burton Harrison (London: Ward and Downey, 1885)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Drawing for "The Story of the Moorish Dish"; ink and Chinese white on card. The book was issued in the United States as: Bric-a-Brac Stories (New York: Charles Scribner's Sons, 1885).

acqinfo.p: Purchased from Charles on the William L. Phelps Fund, 1957

did.unittitle: A Floral Fantasy in an Old English Garden (New York and London: Harper and Bros., 1899)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nineteen drawings in watercolor on paper for endpapers and for illustrations on pp. [1], [2], 6-7, 9, 11, 15, 17-18, 20, 22-26, 38, and 45; also, a drawing with crane and brushes, not used. The drawings are interleaved with the printed version, first edition, bound in green full levant morocco by Riviere & Son. Inscribed on verso of leaf 3: "Mary Frances Crane with the author's love, Dec. 31, 1898."

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Philip M. Neufeld in honor of Catharine Tinker Patterson, 1958.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ink on paper; titled and signed at lower right corner. Crane recounted his visit to Winterburg (Vimperk, Czech Republic), and the flood there on page 347 of his autobiography, An Artist's Reminiscences (1907).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from William Reese Company (Bonhams sale, 2016 June 8, lot 87), on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund Fund, 2016.

did.unittitle: Queen Summer, or the Tourney of the Lily and the Rose (London: Cassell & Co., 1891)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Twenty-seven drawings in black ink and watercolor on paper, inserted in printed large paper copy, first edition, rebound. Drawings are for front and back covers and for illustrations on pp. 1-2, 6, 12, 16-17, 20-26, 28-32, and 34-40; also, a preparatory drawing for illustration on p. 2, not used.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Charles J. Rosenbloom (Yale 1920), 1972.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two notebooks with autograph notes, sketches and drawings made May 1, 6-7, 19, and July 4-5, 7, 1900. Contents include several drawings from nature at the Labour Day at the Crystal Palace (May 1, 1900); notes and drawings from his trip to Hungary; notes for his Line and Form (London : George Bell & Sons, 1900); and notes for his directorship of the Art Department at Reading College.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Robert J. Barry, 1956.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Watercolor on paper mounted on board; signed lower left: "Walter Crane / 1909" with monogram. Inscribed by Crane on verso of mount: "No. 7 / Swedish Twilight / Walter Crane R. W. S. 13 Holland St. Kensington London W."

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Mace Neufeld (Yale 1948) in honor of Mr. and Mrs. M. Katz, 1963.

did.unittitle: Travels with a Donkey in the Cévennes (London, C. K. Paul & Co., 1879)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frontispiece drawing; ink, graphite, wash, and Chinese white on tracing paper, with a note from Lionel Crane authenticating the sketch.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Removed from Travels with a Donkey in the Cevennes , by Robert Louis Stevenson (BEIN 1976 +147); scene described on page 61 of the volume; gift of Charles J. Rosenbloom (Yale 1920), 1970.
